citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
According to necropsy results from Louisiana State University, an adult female Sand Cat, Asha, died of severe anemia
(blood loss) caused by flea infestation. The necropsy report documented numerous live fleas with abundant flea dirt (flea
feces). The animal was also noted to have parasites in the ears (ear mites). The previous attending veterinarian
prescribed a topical flea control medication. The facility was unable to consistently apply this medication because of the
uncooperative nature of the sand cats. The current Program of Veterinary Care states “Appropriate ectoparasite control
as needed for control of ectoparasites and as determined by the attending veterinarian”. According to the attending and
consulting veterinarians, they were considering changing from a topical flea control to an oral flea control, but that change
had not been instituted at the time of Asha's death.
Animals with severe flea infestation may suffer from stress, discomfort, itching, hair loss, blood loss, and death. The
facility failed to provide adequate flea control for this animal resulting in her death.
The facility needs to ensure that appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries are
implemented and followed.

According to the facility Director and correspondence from a state public health official, on October 21st, 2023, an adult
male striped hyena (“Mowgli”) bit the hand of a teenage visitor causing injuries that broke the skin. At the time of the bite,
the visitor was standing in an area near the back of the animal’s enclosure which should not be accessible by the public.
In this area, the hyena enclosure is made of wire fencing with approximately 4 inch by 4 inch-sized openings. The visitor
reached through the wire fence and his hand/arm was bitten by the male hyena. No facility staff members were in the
immediate area at the time of the bite. According to the facility Director, the visitor was able to enter this area at the back
of the hyena enclosure by walking on a pathway through some bamboo. This pathway was blocked by a single strand of
yellow caution tape. No fences or gates were present.
Insufficient distance and/or barriers between animals and the public may result in unauthorized contact between animals
and members of the public. This contact can result in stress, disease transmission, injuries or even death to animals
and/or visitors.
Animals must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or
barriers between the animals and the general viewing public as to assure the safety of animals and the public.
The non-compliance was corrected prior to the inspection on Oct 30, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Critical Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
According to necropsy results from Louisiana State University, an adult female Sand Cat, Asha, died of severe anemia 
(blood loss) caused by flea infestation. The necropsy report documented numerous live fleas with abundant flea dirt (flea 
feces). The animal was also noted to have parasites in the ears (ear mites). The previous attending veterinarian 
prescribed a topical flea control medication. The facility was unable to consistently apply this medication because of the 
uncooperative nature of the sand cats. The current Program of Veterinary Care states “Appropriate ectoparasite control 
as needed for control of ectoparasites and as determined by the attending veterinarian”. According to the attending and 
consulting veterinarians, they were considering changing from a topical flea control to an oral flea control, but that change 
had not been instituted at the time of Asha's death. 
 
Animals with severe flea infestation may suffer from stress, discomfort, itching, hair loss, blood loss, and death. The 
facility failed to provide adequate flea control for this animal resulting in her death. 
 
The facility needs to ensure that appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries are 
implemented and followed. 
2.131(c)(1)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
According to the facility Director and correspondence from a state public health official, on October 21st, 2023, an adult 
male striped hyena (“Mowgli”) bit the hand of a teenage visitor causing injuries that broke the skin. At the time of the bite, 
the visitor was standing in an area near the back of the animal’s enclosure which should not be accessible by the public. 
In this area, the hyena enclosure is made of wire fencing with approximately 4 inch by 4 inch-sized openings. The visitor 
reached through the wire fence and his hand/arm was bitten by the male hyena. No facility staff members were in the 
immediate area at the time of the bite. According to the facility Director, the visitor was able to enter this area at the back 
of the hyena enclosure by walking on a pathway through some bamboo. This pathway was blocked by a single strand of 
yellow caution tape. No fences or gates were present.  
 
Insufficient distance and/or barriers between animals and the public may result in unauthorized contact between animals 
and members of the public. This contact can result in stress, disease transmission, injuries or even death to animals

and/or visitors.  
 
Animals must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or 
barriers between the animals and the general viewing public as to assure the safety of animals and the public. 
 
The non-compliance was corrected prior to the inspection on Oct 30, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
